definition: homosexual (positive term)
dragon/CL:條|条[tiao2]/imperial
surname Long
positive (electric.)/sun/male principle (Taoism)/Yang, opposite: 陰|阴[yin1]
monarch/lord/gentleman/ruler
King Xuan of Qi (reigned 342-324 BC)
Lao Ai (-238 BC), man of Qin famous for his giant penis/in fiction, bogus eunuch and the consort of king Ying Zheng's mother lady Zhao

Lü Buwei (?291-235 BC), merchant and politician of the State of Qin 秦國|秦国[Qin2 guo2], subsequent Qin Dynasty 秦代[Qin2 dai4] Chancellor, allegedly the father of Ying Zheng 嬴政[Ying2 Zheng4], who subsequently became the first emperor Qin Shihuang 秦始皇[Qin2 Shi3 huang2]
King Huai of Chu (reigned 328-299 BC)/later King Huai of Chu (reigned 208-205 BC)
favorite concubine
Duke Huan of Qi (reigned 685-643 BC), one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
Zhang Yi (-309 BC), political strategist of the School of Diplomacy 縱橫家|纵横家[Zong4 heng2 jia1] during the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
King Zhuang of Chu (reigned 613-591 BC), one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
Qin Shihuang (259-210 BC), the first emperor
Fan Li (536-488 BC), politician of Yue state, businessman and economist
King Huiwen of Qin 秦國|秦国, ruled 338-211 BC during the Warring States Period
Duke Mu of Qin, the first substantial king of Qin (ruled 659-621 BC), sometimes considered one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
Han Fei, also known as Han Feizi 韓非子|韩非子[Han2 Fei1 zi3] (c. 280-233 BC), Legalist philosopher of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
Lord Menchang of Qi, Chancellor of Qi and of Wei during the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)

Wei Lao (c. 450 BC, dates of birth and death unknown), advisor to the first Qin emperor Qin Shihuang 秦始皇[Qin2 Shi3 huang2], possible author of the Wei Liaozi 尉繚子|尉缭子[Wei4 Liao2 zi5] text on military strategy
Wu Zixu (-484 BC), powerful politician in Wu/famous as destitute refugee begging in Wu town, cf 吳市吹簫|吴市吹箫
